definitions.definition: Used to specify a choice or preference ; preferably , in preference to. (Now usually followed by than )
examples: I'd rather not have spent all the money, but it really was an emergency.
I would like this one rather than the other one.
I s'pose we 'd better clean the kitchen, but we had much rather not do anything right now .
Tomorrow's impossible. We'd rather you came next weekend.
They'd rather' ve spent the money on a holiday.

definitions.definition: Used to introduce a contradiction ; on the contrary .
examples: It wasn't supposed to be popular; rather , it was supposed to get the job done.
She didn't go along, but rather went home instead.

definitions.definition: Introducing a qualification or clarification ; more precisely . (Now usually preceded by or .)
examples: I didn't want to leave. Or rather I did, just not alone.

definitions.definition: Somewhat , quite ; to an unexpected degree.
examples: It's been rather /quite a good meal overall, but this melon is rather too tasteless.
We had some rather worse news today.
We’ll be seeing rather a lot of you over the next few days.
I'd rather like a cup of tea. - Oh, would you? I'd rather have a mug of beer.

main_definition: Used to specify a choice or preference ; preferably , in preference to. (Now usually followed by than ) [from 9th c.]
secondary_definitions: ( conjunctive ) Used to introduce a contradiction ; on the contrary . [from 14th c.]
( conjunctive ) Introducing a qualification or clarification ; more precisely . (Now usually preceded by or .) [from 15th c.]
( degree ) Somewhat , quite ; to an unexpected degree. [from 16th c.]
